columns.text: In this problem, we need to calculate the NPV of the decision to switch.

To decide if we will change the policy,  we need to calculate the present value  of the cash flow with new policy and the cost of switching. The switch should be made if the sum of PV of cash flow with new policy and  the cost of switching is greater than zero. So, we need to calculate the NPV of switching, and if it is greater than zero, then the switch will be profitable.

Let's look at the given data:

Price per unit=P=\$540\
Cost per unit=$v$=\$395\
Current quantity sold per month=1,080\
Quantity sold under new policy=1,130\
Monthly required return=0.0095

The present value of the cash flow with new policy is 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{PV}&=\frac{(P-v)(Q^{\prime}-Q)}{R}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{(\$540-\$395)(1,130-1,080)}{0.0095}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{\$145\cdot 50}{0.0095}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{\$7,250}{0.0095}\\[15pt]
&=\$763,157.89\\
\end{align*}$$

According to the new policy, the costs are also changing. A company  will have to produce $1,130-1,080=50$ more units at a cost of $\$395\cdot 50=\$19,750$. Also, sales are changing, so the sales that would have been collected this month under the current policy $\$540\cdot1,080=\$583,200 $ will not be collected. The sum od these two components is the cost of the switch. Thus, 
 $$\begin{align*}
\text{Cost of switching }&=P\cdot Q+v\cdot (Q^{\prime}-Q)\\[3pt]
&=\$540\cdot 1,080+\$395\cdot (1,130-1,080)\\[3pt]
&=\$583,200+\$395\cdot 50\\[3pt]
&=\$583,200+\$19,750\\[3pt]
&=\$602,950\\
\end{align*}$$

Now, we can calculate the NPV of the decision to switch as follows 
$$\begin{align*}
\text{NPV of switching}&=\text{Cost of switching}+PV\\[15pt]
&=-\left[P\cdot Q+v\cdot (Q^{\prime}-Q)\right]+\frac{(P-v)(Q^{\prime}-Q)}{R}\\[15pt]
&=-\$602,950+\$763,157.89\\[15pt]
&=\$160,207.89\\
\end{align*}$$

**Since NPV is  greater than zero, the switch is profitable.**
